LINES.text:
Why do birds not collide with one
another when they change direction?

tried to find out how swarms
worked 100 years ago.

At first everyone claps
at their own frequency

and assign very simple
behavioural rules to each one.
Rule One.

Rule two, avoid
each other.

And rule
three, adjust.

Steven Spielberg’s “Jurassic
Park” was a pioneer in 1993

and virtual reality technologies
have for the first time allowed us

without its members crashing into
each other, one question remains.

Think of it like this: Two
bridges stand between the ants

and the food source
creating four different routes.

of just one robot threatens
the whole mission.

What if instead of sending
one, I send 10 or 100 or 1000?

and adaptable than they
could if I just had one robot?

My first instinct is
always to go complicated.

That’s one
side of the coin.

But only 28 countries have supported
a ban of autonomous weapons systems.

Entire regions are affected
when one factor goes out of whack

1 in 10 individuals
on the planet,
Why did they land in Kenya in 2019

then how can an entire swarm made
up of a million of them find food?

into a series of
two option decisions

they will often go somewhere
in between these two.

What we found is, if we
put five or 10 untrained,

At the end of
the 19th Century,

He gathered
788 estimates.

Every single one
of them was wrong.
of all the estimates was 547 kilos

and the ox
weighed 545!

was only two kilograms
off the actual weight.

Just how smart a swarm can be was
demonstrated in a chess game in 1999.

That’s when 50,000 amateurs
took on Gary Kasparov.

to top the chess legend, the
swarm of 50,000 non-professionals

with four levels of skill as well
as online chess star Kevin Bordi.

The first game with Kevin
Bordi was a neck-to-neck race.

then their chances of winning are still
between 60 and 70%.

The crowd would win against simple
programs almost 90% of the time.

of the massed group would
hover between 60 and 70%.

For instance, three
independent doctors’ opinions

are better than one
from a single expert.
